title: Pouring — Pitcher to Four Cups with Sponging
description: The child pours water from a pitcher evenly into four small cups, then sponges any spills. This exercise refines estimation, control of movement, and introduces care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Place a tray with a small pitcher of water, four small cups, and a sponge.
2. Demonstrate pouring a small amount into each cup, going around twice to equalize.
3. Compare the water levels: 'Are all four the same?'
4. Show how to use the sponge to absorb spills and squeeze into a bowl.
5. Let the child practice independently.
6. Return all materials to the shelf when finished.

slides.setup_instructions: Fill the pitcher about two-thirds full. Arrange four cups in a square on the tray.

slides.text: 'Today we have FOUR cups! The challenge is to make them all the same level.'
Pour a little into each cup: 1, 2, 3, 4. Go around again until the pitcher is empty.
Compare all four: 'Are they equal? Which needs more?' Adjust by pouring tiny amounts.
Show sponging: press the sponge on any spill, lift it, squeeze it into the bowl. 'The sponge absorbs the water!'

slides.prompt: Practice pouring into four cups 3 times. Use the sponge to clean every drop. Can you keep the tray perfectly dry?

slides.text: Dry the tray, empty the cups, and return everything to the shelf. 'You poured into four cups evenly!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour approximately equal amounts into four cups and sponge independently?

parent_notes: Four cups increases the estimation challenge significantly. This naturally develops early division concepts — sharing equally. The sponging component teaches care of the environment, a key Practical Life category. Let the child practice as many times as they wish; each repetition builds concentration and refines motor control.

title: Sandpaper Letters — i and Review
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 'i' (short vowel as in 'igloo') and review of all learned letters: s, m, a, t, p, c, r, i.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'i' (on blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /i/ (short i, as in 'igloo'). Repeat 3 times.
3. Three-period lesson.
4. Review all 8 letters, mixing consonants and vowels.
5. Build new words with /i/: sit, rim, tip, rip, pit.
6. I Spy for /i/ objects: insect, igloo, inch.
materials_needed: All previously learned letters (s, m, a, t, p, c, r)

slides.setup_instructions: Place 'i' on the tray. Note the blue vowel background. Keep all review letters nearby.

slides.text: 'Here is another vowel! Remember, vowels have the blue background.' Trace 'i': line down, then dot. Say /i/ as in igloo.
Child traces and says /i/. Three-period lesson: 'This says /i/.' 'Show me /i/.' 'What sound is this?'
Review all 8 letters. Mix them up. Quick flash: hold up a letter, child says the sound.
New words with /i/: /s/-/i/-/t/ = sit! /r/-/i/-/p/ = rip! /t/-/i/-/p/ = tip!

slides.prompt: Build with moveable alphabet: sit, rim, tip, rip, pit. Sound out each word. Can you read them back?

slides.text: 'You know TWO vowels now — /a/ and /i/! Vowels are in every word.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify /i/ and build CVC words with it?

parent_notes: The short /i/ sound is often confused with short /e/ by young children. If this happens, exaggerate the sound and compare: '/i/ — igloo, /e/ — egg.' We will introduce /e/ later. With two vowels and six consonants, the child can now build dozens of CVC words. Keep word building playful — let the child experiment with letter combinations, even nonsense words.

title: Number Rods — Rods 6 Through 10 Review
description: Comprehensive review and practice with the full set of number rods 1-10. The child builds the complete stair and practices counting all rods fluently.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to carry all 10 rods to the mat one at a time.
2. Build the complete stair from 1 to 10.
3. Count each rod, touching every segment.
4. Play 'Show me': 'Show me 8!' 'Which rod has 6?'
5. Compare rods: 'Which is longer, 7 or 9? By how much?'
6. Match all sandpaper numerals to the rods.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large floor space. Have all rods and numerals available.

slides.text: Carry each rod one at a time, starting with rod 1. 'Let's build the complete stair today!'
Arrange all 10 rods in a stair from shortest to longest, left-aligned.
Count each rod together, touching every segment. 'One. One-two. One-two-three...' all the way to ten.
Place each sandpaper numeral next to its matching rod. 'The symbol 7 goes next to the rod with seven.'

slides.prompt: Play 'Show Me' with all 10 rods. Then compare: 'How many more does 9 have than 6?'

slides.text: Return all rods carefully. 'You can count all the way to 10 with the rods!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the complete stair, count each rod, and match numerals 1-10?

parent_notes: By week 5, the child should be developing fluency with rods 1-10. If any numbers are still uncertain, spend extra time on those. The comparison questions ('How many more does 9 have than 6?') build early subtraction thinking. Don't name it subtraction yet — just let the child discover the relationship physically by comparing rod lengths.

title: Rough and Smooth Boards — Introduction
description: The child traces surfaces of varying textures with fingertips, developing tactile discrimination and refining the sense of touch. This classic Montessori sensorial material isolates the tactile sense and prepares the hand for writing.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to the lesson. Wash and dry hands together — clean, slightly damp fingers are more sensitive.
2. Present Rough and Smooth Board Set 1 (one half sandpaper, one half smooth wood).
3. Demonstrate: using the tips of two fingers (index and middle), stroke lightly from rough to smooth. Say 'rough' and 'smooth' as you touch each.
4. Invite the child to feel the difference with their own fingertips.
5. Introduce the second board (alternating rough and smooth strips). Stroke across each strip, naming the texture.
6. Optional: offer a blindfold. 'Can you tell which is rough and which is smooth without looking?'
7. Return the boards to the shelf when finished.
materials_needed: Rough and Smooth Boards (Set 1 — two boards)
Small bowl of water and towel for handwashing

slides.setup_instructions: Place the boards on a table mat. Have the water bowl and towel ready for handwashing before the lesson.

slides.text: 'Let's wash our hands first — clean fingers can feel better.' Wash and dry hands together.
Present Board 1. Stroke the rough side with two fingertips: 'This feels ROUGH.' Stroke the smooth side: 'This feels SMOOTH.'
Invite the child: 'You try. Touch this side... how does it feel?' Let them discover and name the textures.
Present Board 2 with alternating strips. Stroke across: 'Rough... smooth... rough... smooth.' The child traces each strip.

slides.prompt: Close your eyes or put on the blindfold. Can you tell which strip is rough and which is smooth just by touching? Point to a rough one. Now a smooth one!

slides.text: 'Your fingers can tell the difference between rough and smooth even without your eyes! That is your sense of TOUCH.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify rough and smooth surfaces by touch alone?

parent_notes: The Rough and Smooth Boards are one of the first sensorial materials in Montessori education. They isolate the tactile sense and build vocabulary for describing what the child feels. Always wash hands before this work — slightly damp fingers heighten sensitivity. Use only the lightest touch with the pads of the index and middle fingers, stroking in one direction (left to right). This same light, controlled finger movement directly prepares the hand for writing. The three-period lesson vocabulary (rough/smooth) follows the pattern: 'This is rough' (naming), 'Show me rough' (recognition), 'What is this?' (recall). If the child wants to explore further, you can gather objects from around the house and sort them into rough and smooth categories.

title: Read-Aloud: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown
description: Reading Margaret Wise Brown's tender story about a little bunny who imagines running away and a mother who promises to always find him. Themes of love, security, independence, and imagination.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a bunny. He has an idea — he wants to run away! Let's find out what happens.'
2. Read the first exchange: bunny says he'll become a fish, mother says she'll become a fisherman.
3. Before each new page, pause: 'The bunny wants to become a ___. What do you think his mother will do?'
4. Notice the pattern: full-color paintings alternate with black-and-white drawings.
5. After reading: 'Why do you think the bunny stayed? How did the mother show her love?'
6. Discuss: 'If YOU could become anything, what would you become?'
materials_needed: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Runaway Bunny by Margaret Wise Brown

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together. This is a quiet, gentle book — set a calm, cozy tone.

slides.text: Cover: 'This little bunny tells his mother he wants to run away. What do you think she says?'
Read slowly. Enjoy the rhythm: 'If you become a fish... I will become a fisherman and I will fish for you.'
Pause before each transformation. 'He wants to be a rock on a mountain! What will his mother become?' Let the child predict.

slides.prompt: If you could turn into anything to run away, what would you be? What would Mama or Papa become to find you? Let's make up our own page of the story!

slides.text: 'The bunny decided to stay and be her little bunny after all. Sometimes the best adventures are right at home.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell at least two of the bunny's transformations and the mother's responses?

parent_notes: The Runaway Bunny is a Montessori-friendly read-aloud because it honors the child's growing desire for independence while reassuring them of unconditional love. The predictable if/then pattern supports emergent literacy. The alternating full-color and black-and-white illustrations are worth discussing — the color pages show the mother's imagined response, adding a layer of visual storytelling. This book pairs beautifully with discussions about feelings, family, and the natural world. Children at this age are beginning to assert independence; this story validates those feelings while providing emotional security.

title: Pink Tower — Extension with Brown Stair
description: Combining the Pink Tower and Brown Stair materials for the first time. The child discovers new building patterns using both materials together.
instructions:
1. Build the Pink Tower on the mat.
2. Beside it, build the Brown Stair.
3. Now the extension: lay the Brown Stair prisms flat and place corresponding Pink Tower cubes at the end of each prism.
4. The cube + prism of the same rank create an interesting visual pattern.
5. Let the child experiment with other combinations.
6. Discuss what they notice about the relationships between the two materials.

slides.setup_instructions: You will need a very large mat or two mats side by side for this work.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use the Pink Tower AND the Brown Stair together! First, build each one.'
Lay the Brown Stair prisms flat in a row. Place the matching Pink Tower cube at the end of each prism.
'Look! The biggest cube matches the biggest prism. What do you notice about the sizes?'
'Can you find other ways to arrange them together? Build something new!'

slides.prompt: Experiment! Try building a wall, a train, or a city using both the tower cubes and stair prisms together.

slides.text: Take apart your creation and return each piece to its shelf — Pink Tower pieces first, then Brown Stair.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match corresponding pieces and create at least one extension pattern?

parent_notes: Extensions are a hallmark of Montessori education. After the child has mastered each material individually, combining them reveals deeper mathematical relationships. The Pink Tower cubes and Brown Stair prisms share the same dimensional progression — the 5cm Pink Tower cube matches the 5cm x 5cm Brown Stair prism. This is indirect preparation for understanding three-dimensional measurement.

title: Sound Games — Middle Sounds
description: Advancing phonemic awareness by listening for middle sounds in CVC words. The child identifies the vowel sound in the middle of simple words.
instructions:
1. 'We can hear sounds at the beginning, end, and now the MIDDLE of words!'
2. Say 'cat' slowly: /c/-/a/-/t/. 'What sound is in the middle? /a/!'
3. Say 'sit': /s/-/i/-/t/. 'The middle sound is /i/!'
4. Practice with 8-10 CVC words: map, tip, rat, sip, cap, rim, tap, pit.
5. Sort picture cards by middle sound: /a/ words vs /i/ words.
6. This is the hardest sound game — be patient and encouraging.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare picture cards for: cat, hat, map, pan, sit, pin, tip, lip.

slides.text: 'You can hear beginning sounds and ending sounds. Now let's listen to the MIDDLE sound!'
Say 'cat' very slowly: /c/...../a/...../t/. 'The middle sound is /a/!' Exaggerate the middle vowel.
Say 'sit': /s/...../i/...../t/. 'The middle sound is /i/!' Practice with several words.
Show a picture card. Say the word slowly. 'What's in the middle — /a/ or /i/?'

slides.prompt: Sort the picture cards: /a/ words go on one mat, /i/ words go on the other. Say each word slowly to hear the middle.

slides.text: 'You can hear beginning, middle, AND ending sounds now! That means you can hear ALL the sounds in a word!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the middle vowel sound in at least 5 out of 8 CVC words?

parent_notes: Middle sounds are the hardest for children to isolate. Stretch the word out like a rubber band: 'c-a-a-a-t.' If the child struggles, go back to beginning and ending sounds for reinforcement. Only use /a/ and /i/ for now since those are the vowels the child knows. This skill is critical for spelling — the child must hear all three sounds to write CVC words.

title: Spindle Box — Practice and Quantity Building
description: The child independently works with the Spindle Box, building quantities 0-9 with growing confidence. This practice session follows the Week 3 introduction, focusing on independent work, the concept of zero as 'nothing in the compartment,' and self-correction when the final count does not use all 45 spindles.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to choose the Spindle Box from the shelf.
2. Let the child set up independently: spindles in the basket, box on the mat.
3. Observe as the child fills compartments 0 through 9 without assistance.
4. If the child makes an error, do not correct immediately — let them discover it when spindles run out early or are left over.
5. When finished, ask: 'Did you use all the spindles? Are there any left over?'
6. Extension: use rubber bands to bundle each group before placing in the compartment — this emphasizes quantity as a unit.
7. Return materials to the shelf.

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child carry the spindle box and basket of spindles to their workspace. This is their independent work today.

slides.text: 'You know the Spindle Box now. Today you will fill it all by yourself. Start with zero — remember, what goes in zero?'
Step back and observe. The child counts spindles into each compartment independently. Only intervene if the child asks for help.
When the child finishes, ask: 'Did you use every spindle? Let's count the 9 compartment to check.' If spindles are left over or missing, the child recounts.
Extension: 'Let's bundle! Wrap a rubber band around the spindles for each number before placing them in.' This shows quantity as a group.

slides.prompt: Fill the entire spindle box on your own. When you finish, check: are there any spindles left in the basket? If so, find your mistake and fix it!

slides.text: 'You counted from zero all the way to nine by yourself! Zero is special — it means nothing at all. And nine needs the most spindles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child fill all compartments independently and self-correct if the count is off?

parent_notes: This is a practice session, not an introduction — the child was introduced to the Spindle Box in Week 3. The key Montessori principle here is independent work with built-in error control: if the child miscounts, they will have spindles left over or run out before reaching 9. Resist the urge to correct — let them discover and fix the error. The rubber band extension adds a tactile experience of grouping that prepares for later place value work. The concept of zero continues to develop: it is the only compartment that stays empty, which some children find delightfully strange.

title: Continent Study — Africa
description: Introduction to the continent of Africa using the Montessori puzzle map. The child learns to identify Africa on the globe, explores its shape by removing and replacing puzzle pieces, and discovers some of Africa's animals and landscapes.
instructions:
1. Begin at the globe. Point to Africa: 'This is Africa. It is the second-largest continent. What color is it on our globe?'
2. Move to the Puzzle Map of Africa. 'This map shows us the COUNTRIES inside Africa.'
3. Remove all puzzle pieces and place them on the mat.
4. Replace each piece one at a time, naming the country as you place it.
5. Highlight 3-4 well-known countries: Egypt, Kenya, South Africa, Madagascar (island!).
6. Show animal miniatures: 'These animals live in Africa — elephant, lion, giraffe, zebra.'
7. Discuss: 'Africa has deserts, rainforests, savannas, and the longest river — the Nile!'
materials_needed: Animal miniatures (elephant, lion, giraffe, zebra, or similar)
Control map of Africa (labeled, for reference)

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a large work mat. Have the globe nearby. Lay out the animal miniatures on a small tray.

slides.text: Start at the globe: 'Find the continent that is colored orange (or whatever color your globe uses). This is AFRICA. It is very, very big!'
Move to the puzzle map. Remove 3-4 pieces and name them: 'This piece is Egypt — it has the pyramids! This is Kenya — it has lions and elephants.'
'Can you find where this piece goes?' Let the child match pieces by shape. The knobs help with the pincer grip.
Show animal miniatures: 'These animals all live in Africa. The elephant is the biggest land animal in the world!'

slides.prompt: Take out all the puzzle pieces and put them back! Can you find Egypt? Kenya? Madagascar is special — it is an ISLAND off the coast. Match each animal to the continent.

slides.text: 'Africa is a continent full of amazing animals, beautiful landscapes, and many different countries. We will learn more about Africa soon!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate Africa on the globe and name at least two countries from the puzzle map?

parent_notes: The Montessori puzzle maps are a cornerstone of cultural geography education. Each continent gets its own map with color-coded country pieces and small knobs that develop the pincer grip (the same grip used for writing). At this age, the goal is not memorizing every country but developing a sense of the continent's shape, size, and diversity. Let the child explore freely — some children love removing and replacing all the pieces, while others focus on a few countries that capture their interest. Animal miniatures make the lesson concrete and memorable. If you have books about African animals, landscapes, or cultures, leave them out for the child to explore independently. Madagascar is a wonderful conversation starter — 'A country that is an island!'

title: Painting — Wet-on-Wet Watercolor
description: Introduction to the wet-on-wet watercolor technique. The child wets the paper first, then applies watercolor paint to discover how colors blend and spread.
instructions:
1. Tape watercolor paper to the table.
2. Use a large brush to wet the entire paper with clean water.
3. While the paper is wet, touch a loaded brush of watercolor to the paper.
4. Watch the color spread! 'Look how the paint moves on the wet paper!'
5. Add a second and third color. Watch them blend.
6. Let the painting dry flat.

slides.setup_instructions: Tape paper to the table so it doesn't curl. Put on smock. Fill water cup.

slides.text: 'Today we paint with watercolors in a special way. First, we make the paper WET.'
Use a big brush with clean water to paint the whole paper. 'Make it nice and shiny wet.'
Dip brush in blue paint. Touch it to the wet paper. 'Look! The paint spreads by itself! The water carries it.'
Add yellow next to the blue. 'What color appears where they meet?' (Green!)

slides.prompt: Create a wet-on-wet painting using 3-4 colors. Watch how they blend and dance on the wet paper!

slides.text: Leave flat to dry. Clean brushes. 'Wet-on-wet painting is magical — the water does the mixing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet the paper and apply watercolor to create blended effects?

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is a staple of Waldorf and Montessori art education. The technique creates dreamy, blended paintings with no pressure for representational art. The child learns about color mixing through direct experience. Use good quality watercolor paper — it handles the water better. Tape all edges down to prevent curling. These paintings make beautiful cards and gifts.

title: Cutting — Introduction to Scissors
description: Introduction to proper scissor use. The child learns the correct grip and practices cutting straight lines on paper. This is indirect preparation for handwriting and develops bilateral coordination.
instructions:
1. Present child-safe scissors and demonstrate the grip: thumb in small hole, fingers in large hole.
2. Show how to open and close the scissors ('the alligator opens and closes its mouth').
3. Demonstrate cutting paper strips: hold paper in one hand, cut with the other.
4. Start with cutting across narrow paper strips (1-inch wide).
5. Progress to cutting along a straight line drawn on paper.
6. Collect cut pieces in a bowl for art projects.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare several 1-inch paper strips. Draw thick straight lines on larger paper for cutting practice.

slides.text: 'Today we learn to use scissors! Scissors are a tool — we use them carefully.'
Show the grip: thumb goes in the small hole, two fingers in the big hole. 'Open — close — open — close.'
Hold a paper strip with your other hand. One snip cuts across! 'Open the alligator, feed it the paper, snap!'
After mastering strips, try cutting along the drawn line. 'Follow the line like a road.'

slides.prompt: Cut 10 paper strips with one snip each. Then try cutting along 3 straight lines. Save your pieces!

slides.text: Put scissors down open on the tray. Collect cut pieces. 'Your hands are learning a new skill!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child hold scissors correctly and make snips through paper strips?

parent_notes: Cutting requires bilateral coordination — each hand does a different job simultaneously. This is hard! Start with narrow strips that require only one snip. Left-handed children need left-handed scissors. Supervise closely at first, but the goal is independent use. Cut pieces can be saved for collage work. Never say 'Be careful!' — instead, demonstrate safe carrying (points down, closed).

title: Word Building — CVC Words with Two Vowels
description: Building CVC words using both known vowels (/a/ and /i/). The child discovers how changing the vowel changes the word entirely.
instructions:
1. Review all letter sounds.
2. Build 'cat' with moveable alphabet.
3. 'What happens if we change the /a/ to /i/?' Remove 'a', put in 'i'. '/c/-/i/-/t/ = cit? That's not a word! Try another.'
4. Build 'mat' → change to 'mit.' Build 'cap' → 'cip.' Build 'rat' → 'rit.'
5. Find the real words: sit, pit, tip, rip, rim, pin, Tim.
6. Match objects to words when possible.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the moveable alphabet. Ensure multiple copies of a and i are available.

slides.text: Quick sound review. Then build 'cat': /c/-/a/-/t/.
'Watch this magic! I'm going to change just ONE sound.' Swap 'a' for 'i': /c/-/i/-/t/. 'It changed!'
Build pairs: sat/sit, tap/tip, map/mip, rap/rip. 'Which are real words?'

slides.prompt: Build 5 words with /a/ in the middle, then build 5 words with /i/ in the middle. Read each one aloud!

slides.text: 'Changing just one sound makes a whole new word! Vowels are powerful little letters.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read CVC words with both /a/ and /i/?

parent_notes: This 'vowel swap' exercise is a breakthrough moment for many children — they realize that changing one sound changes the entire word. This is the essence of the alphabetic principle. Don't worry if some combinations make nonsense words; the child is exploring how the system works. Real-word recognition comes with practice and exposure.

title: Number Rods — Addition Combinations
description: The child discovers addition by placing two shorter Number Rods end-to-end alongside a longer rod. By matching combined lengths, the child physically sees that 3+2 makes the same length as 5, and 4+1 also makes 5. This concrete introduction to addition uses materials the child already knows well.
instructions:
1. Lay out the Number Rods 1-10 on a large floor mat in staircase formation.
2. Take out the 5-rod. 'This is 5. Let's find TWO rods that, placed together, are the same length as 5.'
3. Demonstrate: place the 4-rod on the mat. Place the 1-rod at its end. Compare to the 5-rod. 'Four and one make five!'
4. Find another combination: 3-rod + 2-rod. Place them end-to-end next to the 5-rod. 'Three and two also make five!'
5. Let the child explore: 'Can you find two rods that make the same length as 6? As 7?'
6. For each combination discovered, say the equation aloud: 'Three and four make seven.'
materials_needed: Floor mat (large enough to lay out all rods)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the floor mat in an open area. Carry rods one at a time from the shelf and build the staircase: 1 at top, 10 at bottom.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to discover something amazing with our Number Rods. Take out the 5-rod and place it on the mat by itself.'
'Now take the 4-rod and the 1-rod. Put them end-to-end, right next to the 5-rod. Look — they are the SAME LENGTH! Four and one make five!'
'Let's try another. Take the 3-rod and the 2-rod. Put them together. Are they the same as 5? YES! Three and two also make five!'
'Your turn! Can you find two rods that make the same length as the 6-rod?' Let the child experiment freely.

slides.prompt: Find as many combinations as you can! Which two rods make 7? Which two rods make 8? Lay them side by side to check. How many different ways can you make 10?

slides.text: 'You discovered ADDITION today! When we put two numbers together, we get a bigger number. Four and one is five. Three and two is five. We call this adding!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find at least two different addition combinations for a given rod (e.g., two ways to make 5 or 6)?

parent_notes: This is the Montessori introduction to addition, and it is beautifully concrete. The child physically sees and feels that 3+2 is the same length as 5. There is no memorization — only discovery. The Number Rods provide built-in error control: if the combination is wrong, the lengths will not match. Let the child explore freely and celebrate each discovery. Do NOT introduce the + symbol or written equations yet — this is purely sensorial understanding. Some combinations to explore: 5 = 4+1, 3+2; 6 = 5+1, 4+2, 3+3; 7 = 6+1, 5+2, 4+3; 10 = 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5. The commutative property (3+2 = 2+3) will emerge naturally as the child experiments.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Greeting Visitors
description: Practicing how to greet a visitor at the door. The child learns eye contact, a firm handshake, and polite phrases — real-world social skills.
instructions:
1. 'When someone comes to visit, we greet them. Let me show you how.'
2. Demonstrate: stand up, walk to the door, make eye contact, smile.
3. Say: 'Hello! Welcome to our home.' Offer a handshake.
4. Role-play: parent goes outside and knocks. Child answers and greets.
5. Practice different scenarios: greeting a friend, a grandparent, a delivery person.
6. Add: 'May I take your coat?' or 'Would you like something to drink?'

items: No special materials — just a door and practice!
slides.setup_instructions: Clear the entryway so the child can practice walking to the door.

slides.text: 'When someone comes to our home, we welcome them. Let me show you what to do.'
Model: stand up straight, walk to the door, open it. 'Hello! Welcome to our home.' Smile and look at their eyes.
'Now we shake hands.' Show a gentle but firm handshake. 'My name is ___. It's nice to see you.'

slides.prompt: Role-play! Parent goes outside and knocks. Child opens the door and greets them. Switch roles! Practice 3-4 times.

slides.text: 'You greet visitors so well! Next time someone comes over, you can answer the door.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child greet someone with eye contact, a greeting phrase, and a handshake?

parent_notes: Grace and Courtesy lessons are unique to Montessori. They teach social skills explicitly through role-play rather than expecting children to absorb them. Keep the practice lighthearted — silly scenarios are fine (greeting a dinosaur visitor!). These skills give children confidence in real social situations. Practice before actual events: 'Remember, Grandma is coming today. How will you greet her?'

title: Nursery Rhymes — Hey Diddle Diddle & Little Miss Muffet
description: Learning two more classic nursery rhymes with dramatic play. Building the rhyme repertoire and phonological awareness.
instructions:
1. Teach 'Hey Diddle Diddle' — act out each silly scene (cow jumping, dish running).
2. Repeat line by line, child echoes.
3. Recite together 3 times.
4. Teach 'Little Miss Muffet.' Discuss: 'What are curds and whey?' (It's like cottage cheese!)
5. Act it out: sit on a 'tuffet,' pretend a spider comes, jump away!
6. Review all previously learned rhymes.
materials_needed: Optional: toy spider for acting out

slides.heading: Nursery Rhymes
slides.subheading: Hey Diddle Diddle & Little Miss Muffet

slides.setup_instructions: Sit face to face for echoing.

slides.text: 'Hey diddle diddle, the cat and the fiddle...' Act out each character. 'The cow jumped over the MOON!'
Echo each line. Child repeats. Then recite the whole rhyme together.
'Little Miss Muffet sat on a tuffet...' Explain: a tuffet is a small stool. Curds and whey is like cottage cheese!

slides.prompt: Act out Little Miss Muffet: sit down, pretend to eat, then — SPIDER! Jump up and run away! Do it 3 times.

slides.text: 'You know EIGHT nursery rhymes now! Can you remember all of them?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite most of each new rhyme?

parent_notes: Nursery rhymes with unusual vocabulary (tuffet, curds, whey, diddle) expand the child's language naturally. Don't skip unfamiliar words — explain them briefly and move on. The silliness of these rhymes (a cow jumping over the moon!) delights children and makes the words memorable. Acting them out adds physical memory to verbal memory.

title: Knobbed Cylinders — Block 4 and Two-Block Combinations
description: Introduction to Block 4 of the knobbed cylinders (height increases as diameter decreases). Then combining two blocks for a more challenging discrimination exercise.
instructions:
1. Present Block 4: cylinders vary in both height AND diameter, but inversely.
2. The tallest cylinder is the thinnest; the shortest is the thickest.
3. Remove, scatter, and replace.
4. Combine Blocks 1 and 4: scatter all 20 cylinders from both blocks.
5. The child must determine which cylinder belongs to which block.
6. Replace all cylinders in both blocks.

slides.setup_instructions: Place Block 4 on the table first. Keep Block 1 nearby.

slides.text: 'Block 4 is the trickiest! Look — the tall ones are thin and the short ones are thick.'
Remove all cylinders, scatter. Replace each one. Use visual comparison and trial-and-error.
'Now for a BIG challenge! Let's mix two blocks together.' Scatter cylinders from Blocks 1 and 4.
'Twenty cylinders! Sort them back into the right blocks and the right holes.'

slides.prompt: Complete the two-block challenge! Take your time — compare carefully before placing each cylinder.

slides.text: 'You solved the two-block puzzle! Your eyes are becoming very sharp.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete Block 4 alone and attempt the two-block combination?

parent_notes: Block 4 is the most complex single block because the dimensions change inversely — as one increases, the other decreases. The two-block combination is a significant challenge requiring careful visual discrimination. Don't help unless the child is truly frustrated. Errors are self-correcting: if a cylinder doesn't fit, it goes somewhere else. This develops problem-solving and patience.

title: Metal Insets — Oval and Curvilinear Triangle
description: Metal inset work with the oval and curvilinear triangle shapes. The child continues building pencil control with more complex curves.
instructions:
1. Present the oval metal inset.
2. Trace the frame, trace the inset, fill with parallel lines.
3. Compare to the circle: 'The oval is stretched like an egg!'
4. Present the curvilinear triangle.
5. Trace and fill. Notice: it has three curved sides.
6. Display both completed designs.

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose colors. Have enough paper for multiple attempts.

slides.text: 'The oval looks like a stretched circle — like an egg shape!' Trace the frame with color 1.
Trace the inset with color 2. Fill with parallel lines in color 3. Try to stay inside the lines.
'Now the curvilinear triangle — three curved sides! It's like a triangle made of arcs.'
Trace and fill the curvilinear triangle. Notice how different the filling patterns look in curved shapes.

slides.prompt: Make one design with each shape. Try different line directions: horizontal for one, diagonal for the other.

slides.text: Display your designs. 'Your pencil control is getting better with every inset!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace both shapes and fill with reasonably parallel lines?

parent_notes: Curved shapes are harder to trace and fill than straight-sided ones. The oval and curvilinear triangle challenge the child to make smooth, controlled curves — excellent preparation for cursive letter formation. If the child's lines go outside the boundary, that's normal and will improve with practice. Focus on the process, not perfection.

title: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Discovery
description: Practicing cards and counters layout while discovering odd and even number patterns through the arrangement of counters.
instructions:
1. Lay out number cards 1-10 in order on the mat.
2. Show the basket of 55 counters (small discs or buttons).
3. Under card 1, place 1 counter in the center.
4. Under card 2, place 2 counters in a column of pairs.
5. Continue through 10, always placing in pairs (one left, one right).
6. Odd numbers will have one counter 'left over' without a partner.

slides.heading: Cards and Counters
slides.subheading: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Discovery

slides.setup_instructions: Lay number cards in a row across the top of the mat. Place counters in a basket.

slides.text: Lay out cards 1 through 10 in a row. 'Now we'll put the right number of counters under each card.'
Under 1: place one counter in the center. Under 2: place two counters side by side.
Under 3: two side by side, one in the center below. Under 4: two pairs. Continue through 10.
'Look at the bottom of each column. Some have a counter sticking out alone. Those are ODD numbers! The matched ones are EVEN.'

slides.prompt: Run your finger down the center: 1-odd, 2-even, 3-odd, 4-even... What's the pattern? Can you predict if 11 would be odd or even?

slides.text: 'Odd numbers: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9. Even numbers: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. You discovered a pattern!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child set up cards and counters correctly and identify odd vs even?

parent_notes: Cards and Counters is the third Montessori math material in sequence (after number rods and spindle box). It introduces odd and even numbers through a visual pattern — odd numbers have a counter 'sticking out' at the bottom. The arrangement in pairs is key; don't let the child place counters randomly. This discovery of odd/even is a child's first encounter with number properties.

title: Smelling Bottles — Introduction
description: The child explores the Montessori Smelling Bottles, matching pairs of bottles by scent alone. This classic sensorial material isolates the olfactory sense and develops concentration, discrimination, and vocabulary for describing smells.
instructions:
1. Present two sets of Smelling Bottles (6 pairs) on a tray. One set has red caps, the other has blue caps.
2. Demonstrate: pick up one red-cap bottle, open it, and waft the scent toward your nose (do not sniff directly). 'This smells like... lemon! It is fresh and sharp.'
3. Pick up a blue-cap bottle, waft and smell. 'Does this one smell the same? No, this is different.'
4. Try another blue-cap bottle. 'This one matches! Both smell like lemon.'
5. Place the matching pair together.
6. Invite the child to find the remaining matches.
7. Name each scent together: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla, peppermint, coffee, lavender.
materials_needed: Smelling Bottles (set of 6 pairs — red caps and blue caps)

slides.setup_instructions: Place red-cap bottles on the left side of the tray and blue-cap bottles on the right. If making your own, fill small identical bottles with cotton balls soaked in scents: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla, peppermint, coffee, lavender.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our sense of SMELL. These bottles have different scents hidden inside.'
Demonstrate wafting: open a red-cap bottle, hold it near your nose, and wave your hand over it to draw the scent toward you. 'I can smell... something sweet!'
Open a blue-cap bottle and waft. 'Does this smell the same? No — this one is different.' Try another blue bottle until you find the match.
Place the matching pair together in the center. 'These two are the same — they both smell like cinnamon!'

slides.prompt: Find all the matching pairs! Open a red bottle, smell it carefully, then find its match among the blue bottles. Place each pair together when you find them.

slides.text: 'You matched all the scents with your nose! Our sense of smell is very powerful. Can you name the scents you found?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 scent pairs?

parent_notes: The Smelling Bottles are part of the Montessori sensorial curriculum and are often overlooked in home settings. They isolate the olfactory sense just as the Rough and Smooth Boards isolate touch. If you do not have the official Montessori bottles, you can easily make your own: use small, identical opaque containers (like film canisters or small jars with cotton balls) and add a few drops of essential oil or a pinch of spice. Good scent choices: lemon, cinnamon, vanilla extract, peppermint, coffee grounds, lavender. Make two of each. The wafting technique (fanning scent toward the nose rather than sniffing directly) is important — it is gentler and mirrors what scientists do in laboratories. Build vocabulary: 'Is this scent sharp or soft? Sweet or spicy? Strong or gentle?' This material develops concentration, discrimination, and the language to describe sensory experiences.

title: Music — High and Low Sounds
description: Exploring the concept of pitch: high and low sounds. The child experiments with instruments and voice to distinguish between high and low.
instructions:
1. Demonstrate high and low with your voice: high squeaky voice, low rumbly voice.
2. Play a xylophone or keyboard: left side = low notes, right side = high notes.
3. Let the child explore: 'Play a HIGH sound! Now play a LOW sound.'
4. Listen to environmental sounds: bird (high), thunder (low), whistle (high), drum (low).
5. Play 'High or Low': you play a note, child identifies.
6. Move your body: stretch up high for high sounds, crouch low for low sounds.
materials_needed: Optional: recordings of high and low sounds

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the instrument where the child can play freely.

slides.text: 'Sounds can be HIGH like a bird tweet or LOW like a bear growl. Listen!' Demonstrate with your voice.
Play the instrument: tap the small bars (high) then the big bars (low). 'Hear the difference?'
Child plays: 'Find the highest sound you can make. Now the lowest.'

slides.prompt: Play 'High or Low' — I play a note, you tell me if it's high or low. Then you play and I guess! Move your body: up high or down low!

slides.text: 'You can hear HIGH sounds and LOW sounds. Music is made of sounds moving up and down!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and produce high versus low sounds?

parent_notes: After learning loud/soft (dynamics) in week 1, we now explore high/low (pitch). These are the two most fundamental properties of sound. A xylophone is ideal because the child can SEE the size difference that creates pitch difference (small bars = high pitch). Adding body movement (stretching up for high, crouching for low) creates a physical memory of pitch.

title: Cutting — Straight Lines and Curves
description: Progressing from cutting strips to cutting along straight lines and gentle curves. Building confidence and control with scissors.
instructions:
1. Review proper scissor grip.
2. Practice cutting 5 paper strips (warm-up).
3. Cut along thick straight lines drawn on paper.
4. Introduce gentle curves: draw wavy lines on paper.
5. Show how to turn the paper (not the scissors) when cutting curves.
6. Cut along the curved lines. Save pieces for a collage.
materials_needed: Glue stick and background paper for collage

slides.setup_instructions: Draw thick straight lines and wavy/curved lines on separate papers. Use markers so lines are easy to see.

slides.text: Warm up with 5 paper strips — one snip each. 'Good! Your hands remember the grip.'
Now cut along the straight line. 'Open, close, open, close — follow the line like a path.'
'Curves are trickier! The secret: turn the PAPER, not the scissors.' Show how to rotate the paper with the other hand.
Cut along a gentle wavy line. 'Slow and steady — you're doing it!'

slides.prompt: Cut out 3 straight pieces and 3 curved pieces. Arrange them into a collage and glue them down!

slides.text: Clean up scraps. Display the collage. 'Your cutting is improving so much!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child cut along straight lines and attempt curves?

parent_notes: The key instruction for curves is to turn the paper, not the scissors. This is a coordination milestone. If the child struggles with curves, make wider, gentler curves first and gradually tighten them over the weeks. The collage combines cutting with composition — the child decides where to place pieces and creates something original from cut shapes.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Review Game and Sand Tray Writing
description: A comprehensive review of all 8 sandpaper letters through games and sand tray writing. Making the review fun and active.
instructions:
1. Spread all 8 sandpaper letters on the floor.
2. Play 'Jump to It': say a sound, child jumps to that letter.
3. Play 'Trace and Race': how many letters can the child trace in one minute?
4. Sand tray writing: say a word, the child writes each letter in the sand tray.
5. Try writing simple CVC words in sand: 'sat,' 'tip,' 'mat,' 'rip.'
6. Celebrate all the sounds the child knows.
materials_needed: All 8 sandpaper letters (s, m, a, t, p, c, r, i)

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the letters on the floor with space around each. Have the sand tray on the table.

slides.text: 'Let's play a game! I say a sound, and you JUMP to that letter. Ready? /t/!' Child jumps to 't'.
Trace and Race: 'How many letters can you trace and say in one minute? Ready, set, GO!'
Sand tray: 'I'm going to say a word. You write each sound in the sand.'
'Write sat: /s/...write s.../a/...write a.../t/...write t. You wrote SAT!'

slides.prompt: Write these words in the sand tray: sat, tip, mat, rip, sip, cap. Shake the tray to erase between words!

slides.text: 'You know 8 sounds and you can WRITE words! That's amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify all 8 sounds and write CVC words in sand?

parent_notes: Review should feel like a game, not a test. 'Jump to It' adds movement and energy. Sand tray writing of whole words is a significant step — the child is encoding (spelling) rather than just decoding (reading). If the child struggles with a particular letter, make a note and give it extra practice during the week. Writing words in sand is less intimidating than writing on paper.

title: Memory Game — Quantities 1-10
description: A Montessori memory game where the child is given a number, walks across the room, gathers that quantity of objects, and brings them back. Develops number sense and working memory.
instructions:
1. Set up a mat on one side of the room with small objects (beads, buttons, acorns).
2. The child stands at the other side with numeral cards.
3. Child draws a numeral card (e.g., 7).
4. Child walks to the object mat and counts out 7 objects into their hand.
5. Walks back. Together, verify: count the objects. Does it match the card?
6. Play multiple rounds. Mix up the cards.
materials_needed: 50+ small objects (beads, buttons, or natural objects)

slides.setup_instructions: Place objects on a mat at one end of the room. Numeral cards stay at the other end.

slides.text: 'This is the Memory Game! You pick a number card, walk across the room, and bring back that many objects.'
Demonstrate: draw card 4. Walk to the mat. Count out 4 objects. Carry them back. 'Let's check — 1, 2, 3, 4. I got it right!'
Child draws a card. 'Remember your number!' Walk, count, carry, check.

slides.prompt: Play 5 rounds of the Memory Game. Can you get the right number every time? Try challenging numbers like 8 or 9!

slides.text: 'You remembered your numbers and counted accurately. Great memory and great counting!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately gather the correct quantity from memory for numbers 1-10?

parent_notes: The Memory Game is a beloved Montessori activity because it combines movement with math. Walking across the room means the child must hold the number in working memory — they can't look at the card while counting. This builds mental number sense rather than rote counting. If the child consistently gets a particular number wrong, that number needs more practice with concrete materials.

title: Continent Globe — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Continent Globe (colored globe). The child reviews the seven continents using the color-coded globe and begins matching continents to their colors.
instructions:
1. Present the colored continent globe.
2. Review: spin and point to each continent. Name it.
3. Montessori colors: North America (orange), South America (pink), Europe (red), Asia (yellow), Africa (green), Australia/Oceania (brown), Antarctica (white).
4. Play color matching: hold up a color card, child finds that continent on the globe.
5. Focus on: 'Where do we live? Where do our food, stories, or music come from?'
6. Begin a 'Continent Book': one page per continent with a tracing and the name.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe on the table. Prepare color cards matching: orange, pink, red, yellow, green, brown, white.

slides.text: 'Each continent on this globe has its own special color. Let's learn them!'
Point to each continent. 'North America is ORANGE. South America is PINK. Europe is RED...'
Hold up a color card: 'YELLOW! Which continent is yellow?' Child finds Asia on the globe.

slides.prompt: Start your Continent Book: trace or draw each continent on a page and color it the right Montessori color. Write the name.

slides.text: 'Seven continents, seven colors! We'll learn about each continent's special things in the weeks to come.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match at least 5 of the 7 continent colors?

parent_notes: The Montessori color-coding of continents is consistent across all Montessori geography materials worldwide. Learning the colors helps children quickly identify continents on maps, puzzle maps, and flags. The Continent Book is a long-term project — each week you can add facts, pictures, or drawings about a specific continent. This becomes a treasured reference.

title: Read-Aloud: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff
description: Reading Laura Numeroff's playful circular story about a mouse whose one request leads to an endless chain of demands. The story teaches cause and effect, sequencing, and the humor of a chain reaction that comes full circle.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a mouse, and someone is giving him a cookie! What do you think will happen?'
2. Read the first few pages. Establish the pattern: giving the mouse one thing leads him to want another.
3. At each new request, pause: 'He got the cookie. Now what does he want? A glass of milk! One thing leads to another.'
4. As the story continues, ask: 'What do you think he will want next?'
5. When the story circles back to the cookie: 'We are back at the beginning! It is a CIRCLE story.'
6. Retell together: 'First the cookie, then the milk, then...'
materials_needed: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie by Laura Numeroff

items: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie book
slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together. This is a fun, lively book — enjoy the silliness of the mouse's escalating demands!

slides.text: Cover: 'Look at this mouse. Someone is about to give him a cookie. Do you think one cookie will be enough?'
Read with energy. Emphasize the chain: 'If you give him a cookie, he will want a glass of MILK.' The child will start to see the pattern.
Pause before each new request: 'He looked in the mirror and noticed his hair needs a trim. What will he want now?' Let the child predict.

slides.prompt: The story goes in a circle! Can you remember the chain? Cookie leads to milk, milk leads to... what? How many things did the mouse ask for? Let's count on our fingers!

slides.text: 'The mouse ended up right back at the cookie! This is called a circular story — it goes round and round. One thing always leads to another!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that the story goes in a circle and recall at least four items in the chain?

parent_notes: This book is a delightful introduction to cause and effect (if/then thinking) and circular narrative structure. Children find the mouse's escalating demands hilarious, which makes it highly engaging. The circular ending is a sophisticated literary concept that even young children can grasp concretely: the story starts and ends in the same place. After reading, you can play a 'chain game' at home: 'If I give you a crayon, what would you want next? And then what?' This extends the cause-and-effect thinking. Laura Numeroff wrote many 'If You Give...' books — if your child loves this one, the series provides wonderful repeated exposure to the same narrative structure.
